title: Sculpture Garden
name: Sculpture Garden
description: The tree collection in the National Gallery of Art Sculpture Garden  is extensive and diverse, making it ideal for a compact tree walk. The two-square block garden was designed by Philadelphia-based landscape architect and designer Laurie Olin. You will find places to be with the crowd, places of sanctuary and always an appreciation of trees. A map of most of the trees planted is printed on the back of the Garden’s brochure. These 20 stopping points deserve special notice. They are pictured in early summer but are worthy of a visit at any time of year.

properties.name: 1. Atlas Cedar (Cedrus atlantica)
properties.description: Cedrus atlantica: One of two Atlas cedars flanking the main entrance to the sculpture garden. The bluish or dark green needles and tall crown distinguish it in the clump of seven Cedrus species clustered around the main, 7th Street gate. They commonly grow to 60 feet or greater in height with a slightly narrower spread.

properties.name: 10.  Southern Magnolia (Magnolia grandiflora)
properties.description: Magnolia grandiflora ‘Bracken’s Brown Beauty’: A dense evergreen for the garden, note how it fills the corner. A relatively compact cultivar of the southern magnolia, it is notable for leathery, glossy dark green leaves on top and rusty brown on the underside. Among the more cold hardy versions. Showy, fragrant white flowers.

properties.name: 11.  Lamarcki Serviceberry (Amelanchier arborea)
properties.description: Amelanchier arborea ‘Lamarcki’: Serviceberries can be multi-stem or single trunk. These multistem cultivars create a dense clump enticing for birds. It flowers before it leafs out (precocious) with small, white pendulous racemes. The fruit is a small, berry-like pome that ripens to dark purple. Birds love them. They’re tasty to humans, too. According to legend, the Amelanchier is known as a serviceberry in nearby mountainous areas because it blooms about the time the ground thaws enough to dig graves. Great fall color with leaves turning orange and yellow and red. Bark is gray with a reddish cast and is ornamental in winter.

properties.name: 12.  Kentucky Coffee Tree (Gymnocladus dioicus)
properties.description: Gymnocladus dioicus: Kentucky coffeetree is similar in shape to the yellowwood. Another legume, it grows taller – 60-75 feet rather than 40. Also flowers in pendulous panicles, generally greenish-white, in May and June. Trees are usually either male or female. The female flower is longer and more fragrant. A great specimen tree for an open space, here they act as a direct contrast to the elms they face on the Mall.

properties.name: 13.  Paperback Maple (Acer griseum)
properties.description: Acer griseum: The paperbark maple is planted for the dark, cinnamon brown bark that exfoliates in big sheets, much like a birch. Each leaf has three leaflets, similar to the box elder, but is a rich, dark bluish-green. Good fall color in the red-green-russet range. A small tree, it’s often planted as here, in clumps for drama. A somewhat fussy maple that hates wind and loves water.

properties.name: 14.  Weeping American Elm (Ulmus Americana)
properties.description: Ulmus Americana ‘Pendula’: This weeping elm’s stately, but gentle shape gives a strong contrast to David Smith’s steel Cubi XXVI.

properties.name: 15.  Dawn Redwood (Metasequoia glyptostroboides)
properties.description: Metasequoia glyptostroboides: The dawn redwood is deciduous evergreen, with lime green to apple green feathery leaves in spring and summer. They turn russet in fall, then drop, while the small cones hold. A tall, narrow and dramatic accent. The dawn redwoods are not on the National Gallery map, but you should be able to find at least one more.

properties.name: 16.  Graft, by Roxy Paine
properties.description: Graft, by Roxy Paine: This stainless steel sculpture of a tree is 45 x 45. It’s flanked by the redwoods and lines up with No. 9, the yellow buckeye. Trees are sculpture.

properties.name: 17.  Little-leaf Linden (Tilia cordata)
properties.description: Tilia cordata: Lindens historically were used to create an allee on Massachusetts Avenue in DC. This dense, closely planted allee, which surrounds the fountain/skating rink is more typical of a European garden allee. These are littleleaf lindens, also known as lime trees in Europe. They tolerate heavy pruning. The fragrant dangling yellowish-green flower in spring makes delicious honey.

properties.name: 18.  Halka Honey Locust (Gleditsia triacanthos)
properties.description: Gleditsia triacanthos var. inermis ‘Halka’: This honey locust is less rangy and has a rounder crown than most of the Gleditsia cultivars. It is thornless and mostly fruitless, two important characteristics in a public park. These honey locusts give garden visitors dappled shade. This is one landscape tree that allows homeowners to have lawn, too.

properties.name: 19.  American Elm (Ulmus Americana)
properties.description: Ulmus Americana: This American elm predates the sculpture garden and has shown resistance to Dutch elm disease. With its broad, dense canopy, it is a good example of why the American elm is so prized as a street tree.

properties.name: 2.  Lebanon Cedar (Cedrus libani)
properties.description: Cedrus libani: The Lebanon cedar is denser, more horizontal with a flatter top. Needles are similar. Height is 40-60 feet, with an equal or greater spread.

properties.name: 20.  Sweetgum (Liquidambar styraciflua)
properties.description: Liquidambar styraciflua ‘Rotundiloba’: The sweetgum has it all: beautiful, star-shaped leaves, lustrous green summer color, a dense canopy, an upright habit, interesting winged bark and great fall color with reds, oranges and yellow, often all on the same tree.  In the landscape, it grows to 60-75 feet. The species has dangling spiky ball fruits, which birds and other fauna love and lawn people hate. This is the fruitless version, which DC has been planting as a street tree.

properties.name: 3.  Blue Atlas (Cedrus atlantic)
properties.description: Cedrus atlantic 'Glauca': This cultivar, better known as Blue Atlas, has the silver-blue cast that makes it popular in formal landscapes.

properties.name: 4.  Atlas Cedar (Cedrus atlantica)
properties.description: Cedrus atlantica: The partner of Cedar No. 1. This cluster of cedars sets the stage, telling visitors they are in a quieter place, shielded from traffic and noise. Turn around and look east out the gate. See how the cedars frame the National Gallery of Art buildings.

properties.name: 5.  Blue Atlas (Cedrus atlantic)
properties.description: Another “Glauca" for color contrast. Note the pyramidical form.

properties.name: 6.  Lebanon Cedar (Cedrus libani)
properties.description: Cedrus libani: As you move through the park, it’s clear these cedars are equal to the man-made sculptures. Look for one more cedar, Cedrus deodora, in the heavily wooded area behind the café.

properties.name: 7.  Lebanon Cedar (Cedrus libani)
properties.description: Cedrus libani: Note the green, almost fleshy cones on this Lebanon cedar. They are larger than those on the others.

properties.name: 8.  Yellowwood (Cladrastis kentuckia)
properties.description: Cladrastis kentuckia: Known as the Yellowwood because the heartwood is yellow, this is among the North American shade trees that are also highly ornamental. Reasons to plant: Flowers in fragrant, pendulous white panicles in May or early June; smooth, gray bark, much like a beech; bright green compound leaves composed of 5-11 ovate leaflets. The fruits are 2- to 4-inch brown pods. The Yellowwood is a member of the pea family.

properties.name: 9.  Yellow Buckeye (Aesculus octandra or flava)
properties.description: Aesculus octandra or flava: Yellow buckeye is a taller cousin of the Ohio buckeye. This one is typical, with a rounded crown and a height greater than 60 feet. Note the palmate compound leaf that is very similar to the native chestnuts and horsechestnuts. The flowers come out in mid-May, and are 4- to 7-inch, upright terminal panicles. As with the horsechestnut, the seed is held in a spiny capsule. Leaf blotch is a problem with yellow buckeye, and this tree is a good example.
